item.title: Serbia Unexpectedly Holds Rates as Caution Tops Growth Pace
item.description: Serbia’s central bank unexpectedly kept borrowing costs unchanged for a ninth month, sticking to a cautious policy approach even as inflation eases and economic growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: The Serbian Central Bank headquarters in Belgrade, Serbia, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. Serbia President Aleksandar Vucic attended events in Russia’s capital marking the 80th anniversary of victory in World War II and is expected to negotiate a new gas contract with Vladimir Putin. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says Rate-Cutting Campaign Is Coming to an End
item.description: The European Central Bank’s interest-rate cutting campaign may soon be over, with inflation and the economy both on track, Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel said.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Mark Schroers

item.title: ECB Is in Good Position to Withstand Future Shocks, Lagarde Says
item.description: President Christine Lagarde reiterated that the European Central Bank is well placed to handle any abrupt shifts in the economy.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Fed Seeks to Preserve Labor Market Lessons in Rewriting Rates Strategy
item.description: The long period of low inflation before Covid taught the Federal Reserve not to fear low unemployment. But the shock of the pandemic reminded policymakers how painful high inflation could be.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: A shopper carries bags outside a Kroger grocery store in Dallas, Texas, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024. The US Federal Trade Commission and a group of states are poised to sue as soon as next week to block the tie-up between supermarket giants Kroger Co. and Albertsons Cos., according to people familiar with the plans.

item.title: Bulgarians Are Getting the Euro, But Half of Them Don’t Want It
item.description: People are growing more concerned about the potential impact on prices.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: This picture taken on May 16, 2025 shows people listening the national antem of Bulgaria during a rally against the adoption of the Euro, organized by Vazrazhdane party in the national Palace of Culture in Sofia. Bulgaria is expected to get a green light from Brussels in June to adopt the common European currency, the Euro -- but the prospect is unsettling many citizens. Bulgaria has been trying for years to satisfy the European Central Bank's (ECB) conditions to join the euro zone, and hopes to adopt the common currency in 2026. The far-right has demanded a referendum on keeping the national lev currency, but its requests have been rejected by both parliament and the constitutional court. (Photo by Nikolay DOYCHINOV / AFP) (Photo by NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: How Sparsely Populated Norway Amassed $1.8 Trillion
item.description: Of all the world’s sovereign wealth funds, Norway’s is one of the most unusual. These giant, state-linked investment vehicles tend to pick and choose what assets they hold to manage risk, maximize returns and further national strategic interests. Not so with Norges Bank Investment Management, which largely tracks global indexes in order to generate an income from the country’s oil and gas revenues.
item.dc:creator: Heidi Taksdal Skjeseth

media:content.media:description: An offshore oil drilling platform in the North Sea in Norway.

item.title: Why Rare Earths Are China’s Trump Card in Trade War With US
item.description: Rare earths are among the most critical raw materials on the planet, deeply embedded in the technologies that underpin modern life. Yet few people have heard of them or know what they do.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: Annealed neodymium iron boron magnets sit in a barrel prior to being crushed into powder.

item.title: Peru Expected to Hold Rates After Surprise Cut
item.description: Peru is expected to hold rates steady on Thursday after a surprise cut last month, while the central bank assesses international economic conditions.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

item.title: ECB’s Simkus Says It’s Important to Take a Pause on Rates
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Gediminas Simkus called for a pause in interest-rate moves, citing “very big uncertainty” over US tariff policy.
item.dc:creator: Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Gediminas Simkus Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Ricardo Hausmann on What it Takes to Win a Trade War
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: South Africa Seeks 15% Tax on EV-Battery Imports, BD Reports
item.description: South Africa’s trade-control agency proposed a 15% import tax on new energy vehicle batteries to boost local capacity and encourage original equipment manufacturers to build units in the country, Business Day reported.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: A worker inserts a charging plug into an electric Mitsubishi Fuso Truck & Bus Corp. truck during the launch of the brewer’s renewable energy programme at the SABMiller Plc Chamdor brewery, a unit of Anheuser-Busch InBev NV, in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Thursday, Jan. 16, 2019. Increased use of solar and wind energy would reduce South Africa’s reliance on coal, which is currently used to generate the bulk of electricity utilized in the continent’s most industrialized economy. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Economy Shrunk 0.3% in April as Tariffs and Taxes Bite
item.description: Sharp tax increases and US President Donald Trump’s tariffs triggered the UK’s biggest monthly economic contraction in 18 months, casting doubt over the Labour government’s plan to fund its spending ambitions with faster growth.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Says No Fixed Position on Future Rate Decisions
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said he has no fixed position on future interest rate moves and that decisions will depend on data.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy De Galhau

item.title: Japan and US Still Far Apart in Tariff Talks, PM Cited as Saying
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba still sees distance with the US when it comes to trade talks, according to an opposition party leader who met with the leader to discuss US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, Japan's prime minister, speaks during a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, April 1, 2025. Ishiba, whose popularity has sagged due in part to frustration over soaring costs of living, has pledged price relief measures to ease the impact of inflation on consumers by drawing on policies in the current and upcoming fiscal year budgets.

item.title: Crypto Nearing ‘Tipping Point’ Toward Systemic Risk, FSB’s Knot Says
item.description: Risk emanating from cryptoassets could soon become a serious threat to the financial system, according to outgoing Financial Stability Board Chair Klaas Knot.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Klaas Knot, president of De Nederlandsche Bank NV, during a panel session to mark International's Women's Day 2025 at the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, March 7, 2025. European Central Bank officials are bracing for tough negotiations over whether to cut interest rates further or hold fire when they next set borrowing costs in April, according to people familiar with their thinking. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Tariffs Prompt Largest-Ever Drop in UK Goods Exports to US
item.description: Britain’s goods exports to the US fell in April by the largest amount for any month since records began in 1997 after President Donald Trump launched his global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Felixstowe. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Romanian Inflation Climbs to One-Year High as Leu Hit Record Low
item.description: Romanian inflation accelerated in May after the leu’s decline to a record low during a recent political crisis boosted costs of goods and services.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

item.title: China Found World’s Pain Point on Trade — and Will Use It Again
item.description: For months Donald Trump pushed tariffs and trade restrictions on China to unprecedented levels, part of a strategy to force Xi Jinping into talks the US president expected would help cut the trade deficit and boost American manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Alberto Nardelli, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: NdFeB alloy strip at the Australia Strategic Materials Ltd.'s Korean Metals Plant, in the Ochang Foreign Investment Zone, in Cheongju, South Korea, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025.

item.title: Trump Open to Dialogue With Kim Jong Un, White House Says
item.description: President Donald Trump remains open to communications with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, the White House said in its latest comments expressing willingness to resume dialogue with the nuclear-armed North, despite little signal from Kim seeking engagement.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un in 2019. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP

item.title: India Central Bank Sends Conflicting Signs With Policy Moves
item.description: India’s central bank under new Governor Sanjay Malhotra is giving market participants conflicting signals about monetary policy as it takes aggressive steps to spur economic growth and lending.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra

item.title: Serbia Seen Resuming Rate Cuts After Long Pause: Decision Guide
item.description: Serbia is poised to cut borrowing costs for the first time since September as inflation approaches the central bank’s target and economic growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Serbian National Bank, also known as Narodna Banka (NBS), in Belgrade, Serbia, on Friday, March 25, 2022. Serbia, which holds presidential and parliamentary elections on April 3, has been maintaining a balancing act between its EU ambitions and its close ties with Russia.

item.title: East African Finance Chiefs Face Fiscal Tightrope in Budgets
item.description: East African finance ministers will be walking a tightrope when they reveal their spending plans on Thursday, with ballooning debt, underperforming revenue and geopolitics challenging planned fiscal consolidation.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

item.title: CDPQ Looks to Trim US Assets as CEO Worries About Stagflation
item.description: The head of Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec said it’s time for the fund to scale back on US investments after years of growth and great returns.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Charles Emond, chief executive officer of Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec (CDPQ), during an event at the Montreal Chamber of Commerce in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Wednesday, May 29, 2024. One of Canada's biggest pension funds says it hasn't been able to deploy the C$10 billion ($7.3 billion) it earmarked for energy transition investments, partly because it finds Asian governments' long-term plans and support inadequate.

item.title: Japan’s Firms See Business Climate Worsen on Tariff Hits
item.description: Japan’s largest businesses turned pessimistic for the first time in more than a year as Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs upended key sectors, a development that could complicate the Bank of Japan’s policy path.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: NZ’s Willis Criticizes RBNZ Handling of Orr Resignation
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis has criticized the Reserve Bank for its handling of former Governor Adrian Orr’s resignation, saying it should have been more transparent about his reason for quitting.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: Nicola Willis Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Sperling Sees Enduring US-China Trade Tensions, Volatility Ahead
item.description: Trade tensions between the U.S. and China are unlikely to ease soon despite a recent thaw on tariffs, according to Gene Sperling of Pacific Investment Management Co., who warns market volatility is likely to persist.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Gene Sperling Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia Inflation Expectations Rise to Highest Since 2023
item.description: Australia’s expected inflation rate rose to 5.0% in June, the highest level since July 2023, according to a survey released by the Melbourne Institute.

item.title: Trump’s Auto Tariffs Strike at the Heart of Japan’s Economy
item.description: Toyota, Honda, Subaru and other Japanese carmakers brace for a profit hit of more than $19 billion as economists flag the risk of a recession and a setback for key wage cycle
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Nicholas Takahashi

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for export in Yokohama in February.

item.title: Asia’s Easing Prices Pave Path for Rate Cuts and US Divergence
item.description: Inflation is easing across Asia as lower food and fuel prices and stronger local currencies against the dollar push down costs. That’s giving the region’s central bank chiefs scope to support their trade-reliant economies as the risk of US tariffs and related uncertainty weigh on the outlook.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey, Katia Dmitrieva

item.title: Trump Says Again He’ll Set Unilateral Tariffs in Two Weeks
item.description: President Donald Trump said he intended to send letters to trading partners in the next one to two weeks setting unilateral tariff rates, ahead of a July 9 deadline to reimpose higher duties on dozens of economies.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Trump said he intended to send letters to trading partners in the next one to two weeks setting unilateral tariff rates, ahead of a July 9 deadline to reimpose higher duties on dozens of economies. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Sipa
